Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics and Stability of Spatially Extended Patterns
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims to further our understanding of cardiac arrhythmias by analysing the properties of spiral waves, which are anomalous electrochemical waves in cardiac tissue that may lead to fibrillation. A particular focus will be on studying how robust spiral waves behave under spatial perturbations in specific model systems. In addition, the principal investigator will study the role of different mechanisms that can lead to complex spatio-temporal dynamics in models of cardiac tissue. The project will include research activities that will train both graduate and undergraduate students.

The project focuses on the spectral and linear stability of spiral waves in reaction-diffusion systems. Building on earlier work in one spatial dimension, the goal is to elucidate spatio-temporal responses to spatial perturbations of spiral waves in the core and far field. The main approach will involve deriving estimates of the resolvent kernel using spatial dynamics and the construction of the spatio-temporal Green's function about a spiral wave. The second part of the project will focus on an analytical approach to backfiring and pulse-splitting in the FitzHugh-Nagumo model using steady-state approximations and geometric singular perturbation theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many biological, chemical, and physical processes exhibit stationary and propagating patterns. Examples are action potentials traveling in nerve axons, excitation waves propagating through cardiac tissue, hexagonal rock formations, and vegetation patterns in semi-arid environments. Despite the wide range of spatial and temporal scales that characterizes these different structures, and despite the variety of underlying mechanisms that causes them to emerge, these patterns have many mathematical properties in common. The theoretical results of this project predict robustness, multiplicity, and stability properties of these structures across scales. They also illuminate when and how these patterns will change shape and stability as parameters in the system are varied and make predictions for when new phenomena, such as spatial-temporal replication of localized patterns, will emerge. The applied outcomes include the development of algorithms to align single-cell multi-omics data, quantify patterns emerging in agent-based model simulations, draw causal inferences from fMRI images, extract information from FRAP experiments, and construct large-scale networks from diary-based survey data to understand infectious disease spreading. The project provided training opportunities for 15 undergraduate summer research students, 11 PhD students, and 1 postdoctoral fellow. The results obtained by undergraduate and graduate students researchers were published in premier mathematical journals and presented at national and international conferences.
